Description: Head of female terracotta figure wearing her hair in a sphendone. Mould-made and following Tanagra types. Broken off at neck where it was once inserted into the body. Mould-made, solid. Hair parted in the middle and drawn down low at the sides; confined at the back by a sphendone. Pink-brown Nile silt fabric with brown surface and grey core, sandy inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Late 4th to 3rd century BC parallels from Alexandria (Tezgör 2007, nos. 1-2, 262). Tezgör, D. K. 2007. Tanagréennes d'Alexandrie : figurines de terre cuite hellénistiques des nécropoles orientales. Musée gréco-romain d'Alexandrie. Études alexandrines 13. Cairo : Institut Français d'Archéologie Orientale.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.375) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5851 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
